Posts.Content: 3 weeks ago my husband started taking 50mg daily of bicalutamide while he awaits surgery. So far all OK except a slight sensitivity in one nipple. Last night he woke with vomiting and diahhera and faint feeling which continues today, does not have a fever. I'm thinking he has the flu but read some men do not tolerate HT well, wondering how long before side effects show? Any experience sharing appreciated. I've tried to research some threads but busy with nursing duties!
Posts.Title: HT while awaiting surgery...flu like side effects?

Posts.Content: 3 weeks ago my husband started taking 50mg daily of bicalutamide while he awaits surgery. So far all OK except a slight sensitivity in one nipple. Last night he woke with vomiting and diahhera and faint feeling which continues today, does not have a fever. I'm thinking he has the flu but read some men do not tolerate HT well, wondering how long before side effects show? Any experience sharing appreciated. I've tried to research some threads but busy with nursing duties!
Posts.Title: HT while awaiting surgery...flu like side effects?

Posts.Content: Hi Wife of T, I am also a wife and we had cancer confirmed a few weeks ago and now waiting for further tests and treatment decisions, 2nd opinion appointments etc and yes the hardest part is the waiting....the days go by so slowly. Best of luck and positive thoughts being sent your way I downloaded and read Patrick Walsh's book which I found very helpful. Also go in to all the appointments and take good notes as you will likely remember things differently!

Posts.Content: Great news!
Posts.Title: Good news!

Posts.Content: Great news!
Posts.Title: Good news!

Posts.Content: It's a nice feeling to know no more appts for 3 months...enjoy!
Posts.Title: Staying positive

Posts.Content: Staples and catheter out and all appears to be fine. Received pathology report also today. Upgraded from Gleason 7 4+3 to 8 4+4....lymph nodes negative for malignancy...one with sinus histiocytosis...2.4cm x 0.9 tumor size...involving 20 to 25%...right seminal vesicles involved by tumor...right lateral margin involved by tumor, distal margin negstive, proximal margin - sent for 2nd opinion...lymphovascular and perineural invasion not identified...pathological staging pT3b pNO pM Comment: Immunohistochemica stain Pankeratin is pending to assess the proximal margin and will be reported in a addedum. This case will be sent for a second opinion. The above is taken from the written report we received. Urologist says to have PSA tested in 3 months and return to discuss next steps based on PSA finding. Any comments on above appreciated and welcomed! We know this is not as good as we hoped.
Posts.Title: Pathology report, Gleason upgraded from 7 to 8

Posts.Content: Staples and catheter out and all appears to be fine. Received pathology report also today. Upgraded from Gleason 7 4+3 to 8 4+4....lymph nodes negative for malignancy...one with sinus histiocytosis...2.4cm x 0.9 tumor size...involving 20 to 25%...right seminal vesicles involved by tumor...right lateral margin involved by tumor, distal margin negstive, proximal margin - sent for 2nd opinion...lymphovascular and perineural invasion not identified...pathological staging pT3b pNO pM Comment: Immunohistochemica stain Pankeratin is pending to assess the proximal margin and will be reported in a addedum. This case will be sent for a second opinion. The above is taken from the written report we received. Urologist says to have PSA tested in 3 months and return to discuss next steps based on PSA finding. Any comments on above appreciated and welcomed! We know this is not as good as we hoped.
Posts.Title: Pathology report, Gleason upgraded from 7 to 8

Posts.Content: Hi Run...thanks for the info. I am happy to receive any info you would like to share. As was the case when first diagnosed, my hubby prefers to take a back seat and let me do the research. Some would call it denial! Feel free to pm if you'd rather. My thoughts at this time are to hit it hard...
Posts.Title: Pathology report, Gleason upgraded from 7 to 8

Posts.Content: Run..you said first post op psa was at 9 months...do you mean weeks?
Posts.Title: Pathology report, Gleason upgraded from 7 to 8

Posts.Content: Yes we were a bit shaken...me more than him as I am more in tune with the numbers etc. My hubby is more of a hands on let's get er done kind of guy which is why I'm on here and not him. He simply said hmm from a 7 to an 8...not so bad. He thought the doc said it it was all contained (which I didn't hear) so he's not concerned about it. At this stage I'm not going to burst his bubble...allow him to heal and then when time comes I'll let the experts advise him. He's just happy today that the damn catheter is out and he's allowed to drive again! Surgeon said he is still confident about a cure. Yes MM keep us posted. Seems like there are a few similar newbies here. Surgeon said with his high psa of 39, there wasn't any point in doing a psa before 3 months as it would take that long to go out of the system.

Posts.Content: Hi Run...thanks for the info. I am happy to receive any info you would like to share. Posts.Title: Pathology report, Gleason upgraded from 7 to 8

Posts.Content: Hubby's pathology was upgraded to Gleason 8, 2 positive margins and seminal vesicle involvement. PSA last week was at zero 12 week checkup. Surgeon is not recommending radiation as says research indicates not effective for this type of cancer...seminal vesicles involved. He says watch and wait...next appt in 3 mths. I am feeling scared about this decision but my husband is very happy cause his interpretation is he doesn't NEED radiation...I want to be positive but am having a hard time...he doesn't know this as I hide it! Anyone have an opinion on no radiation? I guess I was not prepared for this decision and somewhat surprised. My hubby said he was going with whatever the surgeon suggested as he trusts him. Guess I'm less trusting or I wouldn't be posting this!
Posts.Title: To Radiate or not?

Posts.Content: Hi MM...thanks for your response...no lymph node involvement...psa was done at a lab that doesn't measure below zero which we didn't know until we went for checkup. Psa was 39 prior surgery. Staging was pT3bpNOpM according to report. Sorry don't know what assay is? My husband just wants on with his life and doesn't want to see anyone else and in fact said for me not to go on the forum to ask my friends lol I do know from going through the whole catheter and incontinence experience with him that he would not be a good candidate if radiation affected anything negatively...he'd rather loose a few years than put up with any type of incontinence or bowel issues. He's fully continent now and back to work and ready to charge on with life, although he's still quite fatiqued. I caught up on your thread....took a break away from here for a while. How are you doing? I know you didn't receive the best news either...not an easy journey.
Posts.Title: To Radiate or not?

Posts.Content: Thanks all for your responses. Yes Jim the surgeon believes based on research that radiation at any time, because of seminal vesicle involvement, should not be considered because research that concludes it would make any difference. Balancing that with possible side effects...radiation is not his recommendation. If there is recurrence based on PSA, then HT and later chemo if necessary, is his recommended course of action. And MM the lab we had PSA done doesn't measure PSA as fine as others and we didn't know beforehand. I asked surgeon if he should have redone and was told no...just have it done in June at the better lab. And that is end of that. My hubby has already moved on from cancer as he's feeling well and he is fully continent so he's happy and back to work. He doesn't even want to discuss this anymore but I know if he has a detectable PSA he's going to be shocked as he believes he's cured. I've read of other wives who are in similiar situations as mine and they don't want to burst the bubble. Trouble is I guess like Chuck says maybe the surgeon got it all and there is no bubble to burst! I would like my husband to go for a 2nd opinion on this.
Posts.Title: To Radiate or not?

Posts.Content: We had a 'discussion' this morning...he admits it was foolish to a point. He felt OK so thought he could do it....I'm going to show him a video today of what his surgery was as he doesn't obviously have an appreciation of it. He had a slave driver of a father and he pounded it into him (maybe literally) that sitting around isn't allowed. I've been trying to teach him over the last few years that relaxing is OK... in fact, it is essential to one's well being! Catheter comes out tomorrow...duct tape and bubble wrap to the chair sounds like a great idea lol Thank you everyone for your comments...I really appreciate the support on here and all the time you guys volunteer to help out newbies... special thanks to those who are going through their own active battles.
Posts.Title: Post op...how much activity is too much?

Posts.Content: We had a 'discussion' this morning...he admits it was foolish to a point. He felt OK so thought he could do it....I'm going to show him a video today of what his surgery was as he doesn't obviously have an appreciation of it. He had a slave driver of a father and he pounded it into him (maybe literally) that sitting around isn't allowed. I've been trying to teach him over the last few years that relaxing is OK... in fact, it is essential to one's well being! Posts.Title: Post op...how much activity is too much?

Posts.Content: Thanks MM...as the week goes by since our appt and I digest all this, I have all kinds of questions and confusion...I thought radiation was a given and the surgeon's recommendation totally threw me for a loop and my husband's eager embracing of his suggestion rendered me speechless. Yes I am in a difficult position because ultimately it is my husband's decision about his treatment. And he's made it clear he doesn't want me to do any more research and wants me to accept the surgeon's recommendation. But I'm stubborn and this affects both of us so I am going to keep trying and hope he will at least go see the radiology team We saw them prior to him deciding on surgery and they concurred on his decision to have surgery first. I really appreciate you taking the time to care and write all this info. There are so many great people on here and just having others to bounce this off of is so wonderful. At times I've felt alone in this journey but then I come on here and feel supported...thank you everyone!

Posts.Title: To Radiate or not?

Posts.Content: Hubby is on 12th day post op...open surgery...he is bored and wanting to be outdoors doing stuff. I want to encourage him in his recovery and independence. Today he was light shoveling which I was worried about and then he stood on the plow guys truck bumper lightly bouncing up and down as it was stuck. I was horrified as this seemed like a bad thing to be doing. I voiced my disapproval but he didn't see anything wrong with this. I don't want to be the policeman....thoughts from those who've been here and maybe had an anxious partner nagging them lol Am I being overly cautious? I know once he's rid of cathy and staples are out in 2 days, it will be hard to contain him!
Posts.Title: Post op...how much activity is too much?

Posts.Content: Thanks guys ...I needed some male confirmation! I was reamed out for being upset about this today. I will rat him out to the surgeon on Tuesday....ultimately though he's old enough to know this himself. I was angry today as I've sacrificed a lot too these last few months to be constantly by his side and feel the least he can do is follow Dr orders...boy this cancer journey is emotionally difficult.

Posts.Title: Post op...how much activity is too much?

Posts.Content: My 61 y old husbands psa was 29. He had a rising PSA and several negative biopsies before they did a guided biopsy from a 3T MRI. My only advice is don't let them continue to do blind biopsys....get the 3T MRI so they know where to biopsy. My husband did have cancer but thankfully it had not metastasized. He had open RP in January and is back to work now. He didn't have symptoms and was in good health prior to his rising PSA. Best wishes for a speedy diagnosis...if it is cancer, this is a great place to be for lots of info and support. Wish I had found it earlier.

Posts.Title: PSA of 22.39

Posts.Content: Hi everyone, this is my first post, ever in my life to any forum but desperate times call for desperate measures! 61 year old husband's cancer diagnosis was confirmed through biopsy last week. He's had rising PSA and multiple negative biopsies starting Jan 2013. PSA was 4.4 first reading, now 39. Found 1 core from 8 with Gleason 4+3 on recent biopsy after MRI found cancer location in anterior. Surgeon says his cancer is high risk due to his high PSA. He has been given stage of T1 as no noted tumor on DRE but I question whether it would be felt on DRE due to anterior location. Surgeon did say he fears tumor is much larger and more advanced than we realize. Bone scan yesterday is clear. Pelvic scan yet to be done. Open radical surgery has been offered (if scans clear) as best treatment followed by probable radiation although we have not seen the radiation oncologist yet - appt. not until Oct 28th. Surgeon felt during our 1/2 hr. appt. that my husband is surgery adverse and said hormone/radiation may be a better option for him. This is all new to us and we are feeling a bit lost in all the jargon and research. We were set to retire next spring and looking forward to the adventures we had planned. This is now a somewhat unexpected blip in the radar as I'm sure it is for everyone on here. We go back and forth between being very scared and being very optimistic...my husband goes back and forth between 'let's get the d... prostrate out of there' to 'I'm not having surgery, too many downsides'. It's an emotional roller coaster for sure. I am supportive of whatever informed decision he decides to make knowing there are many risks and life altering consequences to any treatment. Any tips/advice/support as we move forward?
Posts.Title: 61 yo husband newly diagnosed with high risk prostrate cancer

Posts.Content: Wow, thanks so much for all of the replies. I am going to take my time and read all of the information tomorrow with fresh eyes and share it with my husband. I will for sure get Peter Walsh's book online tomorrow. We are located in Canada - I guess there's somewhere I can put that in my profile. We do not have access to the daVinci surgery locally but it is no problem to travel to another province for this - the only issue is there are waiting lists and they may not consider my husband because of his high risk situation. Again thank you for all the helpful information.
Posts.Title: 61 yo husband newly diagnosed with high risk prostrate cancer

Posts.Content: Thanks for asking this question.......seems like you guys will be celebrating the same day we will!

Posts.Content: My hubby had his catheter out on 19th too and experienced a small amount of blood Saturday but all OK now. Guess this is to be expected.

Posts.Content: My hubby had his catheter out on 19th too and experienced a small amount of blood Saturday but all OK now. Guess this is to be expected.
Posts.Title: Got a new question

Posts.Content: Wow, thanks so much for all of the replies. I am going to take my time and read all of the information tomorrow with fresh eyes and share it with my husband. I will for sure get Peter Walsh's book online tomorrow. We are located in Canada - I guess there's somewhere I can put that in my profile. We do not have access to the daVinci surgery locally but it is no problem to travel to another province for this - the only issue is there are waiting lists and they may not consider my husband because of his high risk situation. Again thank you for all the helpful information.
Posts.Title: 61 yo husband newly diagnosed with high risk prostrate cancer

Posts.Content: Hi everyone, this is my first post, ever in my life to any forum but desperate times call for desperate measures! 61 year old husband's cancer diagnosis was confirmed through biopsy last week. He's had rising PSA and multiple negative biopsies starting Jan 2013. PSA was 4.4 first reading, now 39. Found 1 core from 8 with Gleason 4+3 on recent biopsy after MRI found cancer location in anterior. Surgeon says his cancer is high risk due to his high PSA. He has been given stage of T1 as no noted tumor on DRE but I question whether it would be felt on DRE due to anterior location. Surgeon did say he fears tumor is much larger and more advanced than we realize. Bone scan yesterday is clear. Pelvic scan yet to be done. Open radical surgery has been offered (if scans clear) as best treatment followed by probable radiation although we have not seen the radiation oncologist yet - appt. not until Oct 28th. Surgeon felt during our 1/2 hr. appt. that my husband is surgery adverse and said hormone/radiation may be a better option for him. This is all new to us and we are feeling a bit lost in all the jargon and research. We were set to retire next spring and looking forward to the adventures we had planned. This is now a somewhat unexpected blip in the radar as I'm sure it is for everyone on here. We go back and forth between being very scared and being very optimistic...my husband goes back and forth between 'let's get the d... prostrate out of there' to 'I'm not having surgery, too many downsides'. It's an emotional roller coaster for sure. I am supportive of whatever informed decision he decides to make knowing there are many risks and life altering consequences to any treatment. Any tips/advice/support as we move forward?
Posts.Title: 61 yo husband newly diagnosed with high risk prostrate cancer

Posts.Content: Wow, thanks so much for all of the replies. I am going to take my time and read all of the information tomorrow with fresh eyes and share it with my husband. I will for sure get Peter Walsh's book online tomorrow. We are located in Canada - I guess there's somewhere I can put that in my profile. We do not have access to the daVinci surgery locally but it is no problem to travel to another province for this - the only issue is there are waiting lists and they may not consider my husband because of his high risk situation. Again thank you for all the helpful information.
